channel.title: NYT > Movies
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: This Year, a Plain Old Ordinary Oscars Was Something to Savor
item.description: After breathing a sigh of relief that the night went smoothly, our critics examine the acting wins as well as the track records of studios and Netflix.
item.dc:creator: A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis
item.category: All Quiet on the Western Front (2022) (Movie)
item.media:description: Michelle Yeoh was surrounded by her “Everything Everywhere All at Once” colleagues after winning best actress on Sunday night.

item.title: Best and Worst Moments From the 2023 Oscars
item.description: Michelle Yeoh made history, Ke Huy Quan made us tear up and Cocaine Bear made us cringe. These were just some of the highs and lows.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Goodman
item.category: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences
item.media:description: Michelle Yeoh with her historic statuette.

item.title: ‘Everything Everywhere All at Once’ Is Big Winner at the Oscars
item.description: The futuristic film from the studio A24 won seven awards, including for best picture, directing and in three of the four acting categories.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.category: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences
All Quiet on the Western Front (2022) (Movie)
item.media:description: Voters honored A24’s head-twisting, sex toy-brandishing, TikTok-era “Everything Everywhere All at Once.”

item.title: Oscars 2023 Winners: See the Full List
item.description: The list of winners for the 95th Academy Awards.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Cohn
item.media:description: Ke Huy Quan accepting the Oscar for best supporting actor for his performance in “Everything Everywhere All at Once.”

item.title: Where to Watch 2023 Oscar Winners: ‘Everything, Everywhere,’ ‘The Whale’ and More
item.description: Most of the night’s winners can be watched at home. Here’s a guide to help you find the honorees.
item.dc:creator: Scott Tobias
item.category: All Quiet on the Western Front (2022) (Movie)

item.title: Ruth E. Carter Becomes First Black Woman to Win Two Oscars
item.description: The costume designer won an Academy Award for “Black Panther: Wakanda Forever,” adding to the history-making Oscar she won for the original “Black Panther” in 2019.
item.dc:creator: Kalia Richardson
item.media:credit: Noel West for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ruth E. Carter with her Oscar for best costume design.

item.title: A24 Achieves Art-House Supremacy With Triumphant Oscar Night
item.description: The independent studio behind “Everything Everywhere All at Once” and “The Whale” became the first to sweep the acting awards and win best director and best picture in the same year.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:credit: Noel West for The New York Times

item.title: Inside the Governors Ball 2023 Oscars Party
item.description: Ke Huy Quan, Ruth Carter and Darren Aronofsky were among the stars and filmmakers celebrating at the academy’s big post-Oscars party.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling, Kyle Buchanan and Sinna Nasseri
item.media:credit: Sinna Nasseri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ke Huy Quan with his Oscar for best supporting actor.

item.title: Oscars 2023 Highlights: ‘Everything Everywhere All at Once’ Wins Seven Academy Awards, Including Best Picture
item.description: Michelle Yeoh made history as the first Asian best actress winner, and Brendan Fraser won best actor for “The Whale.” “All Quiet on the Western Front” won best international feature.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Helen Mirren, Lucy Liu and the Joy of Playing Villainous Goddesses in ‘Shazam’
item.description: The “Shazam!” actresses say they signed on for their first superhero movie because the roles are a leap forward for women.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Vincentelli

item.title: When Best Picture Winners Overcome a Release Early in the Year
item.description: “Everything Everywhere All at Once” isn’t the first top film to have its debut long before awards season. But it is one of the few to go the distance.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: ‘Lumière’: An Actress Destined to Be in the Light
item.description: Jeanne Moreau’s first film as a director is showing for a week at Film Forum, newly restored and seven minutes longer than its 1976 U.S. release.
item.dc:creator: J. Hoberman
item.media:description: Jeanne Moreau in “Lumière.” Moreau’s character, Sarah, is a benign star who is in control of her life (and wardrobe).

item.title: Best Oscars Red Carpet Looks: Angela Bassett, Cate Blanchett and More
item.description: The greater the fashion risk, the greater the reward.
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk
item.media:credit: Jutharat Pinyodoonyachet for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mandarin collar was a detail specifically requested by the actress Hong Chau for her satin Prada gown.

item.title: The Oscars TV Broadcast Is Becoming Increasingly Ordinary
item.description: A show that’s become a shrink-wrapped, anodyne exercise stuck safely to the script.
item.dc:creator: Mike Hale
item.media:description: As Oscars host, Jimmy Kimmel got off a few good lines but mostly played it safe.

item.title: Why Oscar Attendees Were Wearing Blue Ribbons
item.description: The pins were initiated by the United Nations Refugee Agency to support people who fled their homes to escape persecution.
item.dc:creator: Kalia Richardson
item.media:description: The animated-feature Oscar winner Guillermo del Toro was among those wearing blue ribbons at the ceremony.

item.title: Michelle Yeoh Makes Oscar History as First Asian to Win Best Actress
item.description: All season long the star of “Everything Everywhere All at Once” has spoken of the obstacles she and other people of color faced in Hollywood.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Sperling
item.media:description: Michelle Yeoh with her historic statuette.

item.title: The Daniels Win Best Director for ‘Everything, Everywhere All At Once’
item.description: Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert won for their multiverse mash-up, “Everything Everywhere All at Once,” making them the rare set of paired directors to win the big prize.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:description: Daniel Scheinert and Daniel Kwan accepting the award for best director.

item.title: ‘Naatu Naatu’ From ‘RRR’ Wins Oscar for Best Original Song
item.description: The rollicking dance hit beat out two songs featuring American pop megastars.
item.dc:creator: Julia Jacobs
item.media:description: Chandrabose and M. M. Keeravani accept the best original song award for “Naatu Naatu,” from “RRR.”

item.title: Lady Gaga Wipes Off Makeup for Oscars Performance of ‘Hold My Hand’
item.description: The artist wasn’t even set to take the stage. Instead she exchanged her initially glamorous look for a stripped-down one to suit her intense delivery.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.media:description: Lady Gaga opting for a minimal look onstage.

item.title: Jamie Lee Curtis Wins First Oscar for Best Supporting Actress
item.description: “I know it looks like I’m standing up here by myself, but I am not. I am hundreds of people,” she said in her acceptance speech.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:description: Jamie Lee Curtis savoring her victory on Sunday.

item.title: Jimmy Kimmel Addressed ‘the Slap’ in His Opening Monologue
item.description: Kimmel’s remarks also included joking jabs at some of Hollywood’s most famous figures.
item.dc:creator: Nancy Coleman and Matt Stevens
item.media:description: Jimmy Kimmel wasted little time acknowledging recent snafus at the Oscars, including Will Smith’s infamous slap of Chris Rock.

item.title: Ke Huy Quan Wins Best Supporting Actor Oscar, Capping Remarkable Comeback
item.description: “My journey started on a boat. I spent a year in a refugee camp. And somehow, I ended up here on Hollywood’s biggest stage,” he said in his acceptance speech.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.media:description: Ke Huy Quan accepting the Oscar for best supporting actor.

item.title: How Will Smith’s Slap Has Changed the Oscars
item.description: Here’s a look at the fallout from last year’s Oscars, when Will Smith slapped Chris Rock onstage.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Goodman
item.media:description: Chris Rock, left, and Will Smith just after the Slap.

item.title: What Do You Think of the Oscars Show?
item.description: The Times invites readers to share their comments and observations about the 2023 Academy Awards.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Adam Brody Feels All the Feels With Surfing, ‘Avatar’ and Cate Le Bon
item.description: The “Shazam!” star revives himself with sprinkle doughnuts, Frank Black’s “Teenager of the Year” and daily naps.
item.dc:creator: Kathryn Shattuck

item.title: Trial in ‘Argentina, 1985’ Began Quest for Justice That Continues Today
item.description: “Argentina, 1985” has resurrected the country’s military rule, which ended 40 years ago. The quest persists to hold those accused of crimes against humanity accountable.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Alcoba
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Anita Pouchard Serra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pictures of missing people at the Naval Mechanics School, also known as the ESMA, a former clandestine center for detention, torture and killings, in Buenos Aires.

item.title: Brett Goldstein Faces Life After ‘Ted Lasso’
item.description: The Apple TV+ show’s breakout star is preparing to play a Marvel movie god when he’s not working on the hit streaming series “Shrinking.” But what he’s really after is human connection.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Egner
item.media:credit: Magdalena Wosinska for The New York Times
item.media:description: “I used to be very, very miserable and had a quite dark brain, and I’ve worked very hard at changing that,” Brett Goldstein said. “But it’s there.”

item.title: Why the Oscars Red Carpet Went Champagne
item.description: The 2023 Academy Awards carpet’s champagne hue — a break with a 62-year tradition of the bright red rug — is the latest arrival rug to opt for a colorful palette.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr
item.category: Academy of Television Arts and Sciences
item.media:description: Clockwise from left: The Emmy’s carpet in 2022; ‘Avatar: The Way of Water’ premiere in 2022; and the premiere of ”Black Panther: Wakanda Forever” in 2022; the Golden Globe Awards in 2023.

item.title: Five International Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include a Kafkaesque South Indian comedy, a delirious British noir caper scripted by Alan Moore and a Czech body-horror movie that’ll get under your skin.
item.dc:creator: Devika Girish

item.title: Five Children’s Movies to Stream Now
item.description: This month’s picks include a musical adaptation of a Roald Dahl classic, an animated coming-of-age story and an assortment of lovable farm animals.
item.dc:creator: Dina Gachman
item.category: The Biggest Little Farm: The Return (Movie)

item.title: In ‘Scream VI,’ Ghostface Takes the 1 Train
item.description: In turning the subway into a vehicle of horror, the movie gets a number of things right — and a few wrong. But verisimilitude wasn’t the filmmakers’ main goal.
item.dc:creator: Esther Zuckerman

item.title: ‘Chang Can Dunk’ Review: That’s a Man’s Jam
item.description: A short teen channels his inner Kobe Bryant in this exhilarating, warmhearted Disney+ basketball comedy.
item.dc:creator: Calum Marsh
item.media:description: From left, Zoey Renee, Bloom Li, Dexter Darden and Ben Wang in “Chang Can Dunk.”

item.title: ‘A Doll’s House’ Review: Jessica Chastain Plots an Escape
item.description: Jamie Lloyd’s compelling, surgically precise revival of Ibsen’s 1879 drama throbs like an episode of “CSI: Norway.”
item.dc:creator: Jesse Green
item.media:description: Jessica Chastain and Arian Moayed as Nora and Torvald Helmer in “A Doll’s House” at the Hudson Theater. The modernized script, our critic writes, leaves the dialogue raw and red, as if exfoliated.

item.title: Robert Blake, ‘Baretta’ Star Acquitted in Wife’s Murder, Dies at 89
item.description: His film and TV career began with “Our Gang” comedies and was highlighted by his performance as a killer in “In Cold Blood.” But he led a tempestuous life.
item.dc:creator: Douglas Martin
item.media:description: Robert Blake in a scene from his 1970s television series “Baretta,” which ran for three years. He played a detective with a pet cockatoo named Fred.

item.title: ’65’ Review: An Extraterrestrial Adam Driver Lands on Earth
item.description: Millions of years ago, a guy from another planet landed on this one. Like most survivors, he had a moody little girl with him.
item.dc:creator: A.O. Scott
item.media:description: Adam Driver and Ariana Greenblatt in “65,” directed by Scott Beck and Bryan Woods.

item.title: ‘Stonewalling’ Review: A Young Woman’s Exchange Value
item.description: In this haunting drama, a 20-year-old Chinese woman struggles to find her place in a country where she faces a series of seemingly impossible hurdles.
item.dc:creator: Manohla Dargis
item.media:description: Huang Xiaoxiong, left, and Yao Honggui in “Stonewalling,” which takes place in Changsha, the capital of Hunan province.

item.title: Oscars 2023 Predictions: Who Will Win Best Picture, Actor and Actress?
item.description: “Everything Everywhere All at Once” is the favorite, but “All Quiet on the Western Front” could be a spoiler. Here’s how our expert is marking his ballot.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan
item.category: All Quiet on the Western Front (2022) (Movie)
item.media:credit: From top: A24; David Bornfriend/A24; Reiner Bajo/Netflix
item.media:description: From top, leading contenders include Brendan Fraser in “The Whale”: Michelle Yeoh in “Everything Everywhere All at Once”: and “All Quiet on the Western Front,” featuring Felix Kammerer.

item.title: ‘99 Moons’ Review: On-Again, Off-Again
item.description: Instead of an engaging erotic romance, the film delivers a dull narrative of two lovers caught in a cycle of getting together and falling apart.
item.dc:creator: Claire Shaffer
item.media:description: In “99 Moons,” Valentina Di Pace and Dominik Fellmann play lovers who repeatedly pursue each other, get together and then break up over misunderstandings.

item.title: ‘Punch’ Review: Hitting at the Heart
item.description: Welby Ings’s keenly observant debut feature follows a young, promising boxer whose priorities shift.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Turner
item.media:description: Jordan Oosterhof, left, and Tim Roth in “Punch.”

item.title: As a Film Revives Elvis’s Legacy, the Presleys Fight Over His Estate
item.description: After the death of Lisa Marie Presley, Elvis’s ex-wife initiated a legal battle with her granddaughter over control of the family trust.
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:description: Priscilla Presley, left, and her daughter, Lisa Marie Presley, flanking Austin Butler at the Golden Globe Awards in January.

item.title: ‘Unicorn Wars’ Review: Teddy Bears in Battle
item.description: The contrast between this animated film’s grim subject matter and its bubbly animation style is a big part of what makes it so creepy, our critic writes.
item.dc:creator: Beatrice Loayza
item.media:description: “Unicorn Wars” follows two sibling bears, Bluey and Tubby, as they train for battle in the forest and ingest hallucination-inducing worms.

item.title: ‘Rewind & Play’ Review: Thelonious Monk Dazzles Even When an Interview Falls Flat
item.description: Alain Gomis’s documentary uses rushes from a 1969 French TV interview to make a smart indictment of music industry bias and offer viewers a subtle tribute to Monk.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Kennedy
item.media:description: Thelonious Monk in “Rewind & Play.”

item.title: ‘The Magic Flute’ Review: Mozart Meets C.G.I., With Help From a Tween
item.description: A young tenor enters a world enlivened by computer graphics at a school devoted to the composer’s works in this Roland Emmerich-inspired film.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Kenny
item.media:description: Jack Wolfe in “The Magic Flute.”

item.title: ‘Champions’ Review: Following the Playbook
item.description: This film directed by Bobby Farrelly has elements that recall “Kingpin” and “There’s Something About Mary.” But the ratio of tastelessness to sentimentality has been reversed.
item.dc:creator: Ben Kenigsberg
item.media:description: From left, Casey Metcalfe, James Day Keith, Woody Harrelson, Ashton Gunning and Tom Sinclair in “Champions.”

item.title: ‘Luther: The Fallen Sun’ Review: Psycho Filler
item.description: A smoldering Idris Elba is no match for the preposterousness of this feature-length Netflix continuation of the popular BBC crime thriller.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis
item.media:description: Idris Elba in “Luther: The Fallen Sun.”

item.title: Cautionary Climate Tales That Give People Pause When They Press Play
item.description: The India-born director Joshua Ashish Dawson builds digital worlds that ruminate on the future shock of environmental destruction in the real world.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Wallis

item.title: With Its Future at Stake, the Academy Tries to Fix the Oscars (Again)
item.description: The awards telecast has been losing viewers for years. New leadership wants to reverse that starting Sunday, and ensure the financial well-being of the organization.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.category: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Janet Yang, the president of the academy, and Bill Kramer, its chief executive, want to make the Oscars feel more approachable to more viewers.

item.title: Lukas Gage on the Audition That Went Awry, ‘You’ and Writing His Own Ticket
item.description: Three years after his apartment was shamed by a director during a video tryout, the “You” actor is taking on his first lead role — in a film he co-wrote.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Spencer
item.media:credit: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times
item.media:description: When a filmmaker, not realizing the Zoom mic was on, belittled his apartment, Lukas Gage said, “I remember having this weird feeling in the pit of my stomach afterward, like, why am I judging where I’m at in my 20s, at the beginning of my career?”

item.title: Topol, Star of ‘Fiddler on the Roof’ Onscreen and Onstage, Dies at 87
item.description: Wide acclaim for his portrayal of Tevye helped make him, according to one newspaper, “Israel’s most famous export since the Jaffa orange.”
item.dc:creator: Margalit Fox
item.media:credit: United Archives/Hulton Archive, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Topol as Tevye in the movie version of “Fiddler on the Roof.” The character is a weary, tradition-bound Everyman who argues with God, bemoans his lot as the penurious father of five daughters and lives warily amid the pogroms of Czarist Russia.

item.title: ‘Scream VI’ Review: Ghostface and Meta Commentary Are Back
item.description: Ghostface and meta commentary are back in this sequel, yet the weight of obligations to the dictates of the franchise ultimately drags it down.
item.dc:creator: Jason Zinoman
item.media:description: Melissa Barrera, left, and Jenna Ortega in “Scream VI.”

item.title: Bert I. Gordon, Auteur of Mutant Monster Movies, Dies at 100
item.description: Despite low budgets and years of mostly negative reviews, he gained a cult following for his giant villains, homemade effects and preposterous plotlines.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:description: From left, Basil Rathbone, Estelle Winwood and Bert I. Gordon on the set of “The Magic Sword” (1962), one of the first of the roughly 25 films Mr. Gordon produced, directed and often wrote.
